title: The I-Space Framework
text:
Un pilar fundamental sobre el que se sostiene mi cosmovisión es el esquema conceptual I-Space (Boisot 1998). Es muy complejo y los invito a explorarlo de primera mano porque el autor aborda la complejidad socio-económicos en términos [informacionales](/posts/20231111-dataInformationKnowledge/index.qmd) como nadie. Su análisis de la economía del conocimiento y su explicación del cambio tecnológico son excelentes. Lamentablemente es un autor prácticamente desconocido en la literatura económica.
Yo sólo voy a introducir algunos de sus elementos básicos. Su marco teórico se llama I-Space, o Information Space, justamente porque permite representar flujos y activos de información en un espacio de tres dimensiones. Estas tres dimensiones son los grados de codificación, abstracción y difusión. Al ser evaluadas en grados, al interior de cada dimensión la información se representa en términos relativos.



Representación del I-Space (adaptado de Boisot 1995 y Boisot et al., 2011)


La codificación representa la división en categorías, como conceptualizar ideas o guardar cosas en lugares específicos (ej. ordenar tu ropa en cajones según su tipo). Boisot (1998, 42–47) lo define como el costo de procesamiento de datos que implica distinguir y categorizar cosas o hechos. Lógicamente, codificar es más difícil cuando la cantidad de datos a procesar es mayor. Es decir, cuantas más cosas se tengan en cuenta, más difícil se hace clasificar algo. Una buena manera de entenderlo para mi es pensar en clasificaciones diferentes para una misma cosa, como los indicadores de pobreza. Es más fácil definir un hogar como pobre mediante una sola variable (umbral de ingresos) que mediante varias (pobreza multidimensional).
La abstracción refiere justamente al número de categorías necesarias para clasificar algo. Clasificaciones basadas en menos categorías son abstractas que aquellas que requieran más. Volviendo al ejemplo anterior, etiquetar un hogar como pobre en base a ingresos se puede considerar más abstracto que hacerlo mediante criterios múltiples[^1]. En términos de Boisot (Boisot 1998, ibid), la abstracción permite ahorros adicionales en los costos de procesamiento de información ya que genera asociaciones entre categorías (ingreso-pobreza).
Por último aparece la difusión, que retrata el acceso a la información dentro de una determinada población. La difusión entendida de esta manera depende de varios factores. En parte, está influenciada por los grados de abstracción y codificación, ya que clasificaciones más abstractas reducen el costo de transmitir de información. Continuando nuestro ejemplo de asociar pobreza con ingresos, si ambos indicadores fuesen igual de eficaces en representar la pobreza, sería más fácil difundir la clasificación de un hogar pobre según sus ingresos que ir a revisar las condiciones materiales concretas que tiene para determinar si es pobre o no ). Otros factores factores decisivos en el grado de difusión son las tecnologías de comunicación y los codebooks o marcos interpretativos, ya que afectan la facilidad con la cual podemos transmitir información y desarrollar la capacidad de interpretarla correctamente.
Utilizar estas tres dimensiones nos permite representar espacialmente, y en términos relativos, cualquier tipo de información. Siguiendo con nuestra comparación de indicadores de pobreza, podríamos representarlos de la siguiente manera en el I-Space:



Representación del indices de pobreza en I-Space (adaptado de Boisot (1995) y Boisot et al., (2011)). ING refiere a indices de pobreza basados en umbrales de ingresos y MUL a aquellos de carácter multidimensional.


Vemos el indicador por ingresos (ING) más abajo, a la izquierda y al fondo de la figura. En cambio, el indicador multidimensional (MUL) ofrece una alternativa informacional menos abstracta y difundida pero más codificada, ubicándose por tanto en zonas más elevadas y hacia adelante. Así como, de forma ilustrativa, podemos comparar indicadores de pobreza, el I-Space nos permite ilustrar y comparar todo tipo de objetos informacionales.
A su vez, la comparación y el análisis de estos objetos puede permite pensar, por ejemplo, alternativas estratégicas de comunicación o acción. Para mi es particularmente interesante el uso de I-Space en entornos sociales, ya que permite representar agentes, su conocimiento, su aprendizaje y la evolución de su comportamiento.
Pero para ello, además del I-Space, es necesario: 1) demarcar información de datos y conocimiento; 2) incorporar otros conceptos de Boisot relacionado al conocimiento en entornos sociales.
[^1: Utilizo el condicional aquí porque es fundamental considerar también la eficacia que las categorías tienen para representar aquello que dicen representar. Más allá de la idea de pobreza que tengamos, una persona con infinitas propiedades y ahorros pero con cero ingresos no pertenece al universo de los pobres. Por otro lado, sí podemos asociar una persona que cumplen con los criterios de pobreza multidimencional, como tener acceso a agua potable o electricidad.]




References

Boisot, Max. 1995. Information Space: A Framework for Learning in Organizations, Institutions and Culture. Routledge.


———. 1998. Knowledge Assets: Securing Competitive Advantage in the Information Economy. OUP Oxford.


Boisot, Max, Markus Nordberg, Saïd Yami, and Bertrand Nicquevert. 2011. Collisions and Collaboration: The Organization of Learning in the ATLAS Experiment at the LHC. OUP Oxford.

title: Mis principios cosmológicos
text:
En los últimos años, gracias a tener que enfrentarme con el desgastante proceso de escribir una tesis doctoral, he podido darle bastante forma a mi manera de pensar e interpretar los fenómenos.
Después de tanto explorar ideas relativas a la producción del conocimiento, me siento en la necesidad de establecer de manera explícita algunos rasgos de mi siempre cambiante base cosmológica. Van entonces cinco aspectos bien generales que te acercaran un poco a mi manera de pensar:

Interpreto los procesos físicos no solo en términos materiales sino también informacionales. Concibo la infinidad del universo como flujos constantes de datos e información. La teoría de información de Shannon, la mecánica estádistica, y la idea de entropía me parecen facinantes.
Abrazo la complejidad y la emergencia. Considero que los procesos que acontecen son necesariamente inciertos, aunque también influenciables.
A consecuencia de lo influenciable, adhiero al pragmatismo en su deseo y continua búsqueda de transformación.
Creo que la educación y la colaboración son el mejor camino para desarrollar capacidades de transformación en entornos sociales.
Las capacidades de transformación son un elemento transcendental para la producción social de conocimiento. Mediante el aprendizaje es posible replicar, distribuir, transformar y utilizar información de manera eficiente.

Estos 5 principios, que combinan diversos aspectos cosmológicos, ontológicos y epistemológicos, hacen que mi interpretación del mundo sea de cierta manera. La idea de “conocimiento” ocupa un lugar central, ya que funciona como eje conceptual que atraviesa e inter-conecta mis principios. Dos aspectos relacionados mi interpretación del conocimiento quiero traer a colación: la relación entre datos, información, y conocimiento; y la representación del conocimiento como activo y flujo en un espacio de tres dimensiones.

title: Ian Hulskamp
text:
Hi there!

I am Ian, and I am about to complete my doctorate in the Society of Information and Knowledge at the Universitat Oberta de Catalunya (UOC). While I deeply appreciate academic research, I am currently seeking new horizons that bring me closer to the world of action and practical application.
The purpose of this website is to build bridges towards more concrete environments that are connected to the territory. In this space, I not only introduce myself but also share insights about my skills, my interests, and my way of thinking.
In the recent years of my professional journey, my focus has revolved around collaborations between academic and business organizations. I have learned how various mechanisms of social interaction can promote the production and dissemination of knowledge. It’s fascinating that, regardless of their specifics, these mechanisms can be identified and designed to enhance knowledge production, learning, and innovation in all types of organizations.

title: About
text:
If you’re looking for a concise and straightforward version of my academic and professional experience, I invite you to check out my CV.
As an Economist by training, I found my niche in the realm of innovation and knowledge. Curiosity and a passion for learning have allowed me to navigate the challenging and enriching path of my doctoral journey. Along this path, I’ve developed a wide range of skills necessary for planning and executing a research project.
With my thesis now in the process of review, I am eager to explore new directions. I would like to have more direct contact with reality. I don’t want to merely evaluate but also to execute, to implement improvements and witness their continuous and progressive evolution. While my love for theoretical research and abstract concepts is undeniable, I aspire to find a role that enables me to assist organizations in improving their connection with the environment and strengthening their knowledge base.


 















Before embarking on my doctorate in the Society of Information and Knowledge at the Universitat Oberta de Catalunya (UOC), I completed a dual master’s degree in “Economics of Knowledge and Innovation” and “Economic Policy”. For my master’s, I was awarded a prestigious Erasmus Mundus scholarship, which took me to the Università degli Studi di Torino in Italy for a year, followed by a year at Université Paris Cité in France. During this period, I also spent time at the Université de Bordeaux while working on my master’s thesis.
Before my European experience, I gained valuable work experience during and after completing my Bachelor’s degree in Economics at the University of Buenos Aires. I was selected as an intern at the Buenos Aires office of CEPAL, the United Nations Economic Commission for Latin America and the Caribbean, where I later worked as a consultant on various economic indicator development projects, including a Synthetic Economic Activity Indicator and a Price Index. Additionally, I served as an assistant professor in macroeconomics at the University Torcuato di Tella and as an adjunct professor in a summer course at the National University of Lomas de Zamora.
For two years, I had the privilege of being a research fellow at the Center for Research in Epistemology of Economic Sciences (CIECE) at the University of Buenos Aires, thanks to a national scholarship. Prior to migrating for my studies, I grew up in the beautiful city of San Carlos de Bariloche in the northwestern region of Patagonia, Argentina.








In addition to my academic work, I am passionate about sports and physical activity in general. Just as I train my mind, I also exercise my body. I enjoy climbing and running. I also find pleasure in Theatrical Impro, and I aspire to create a graphic humor book at some point in my life.
Beyond these recreational and leisure activities, I can also share a bit about my academic and professional interests.

title: My Skills
text:
Throughout my education and professional journey, I’ve developed a range of skills related to the use of various methods and tools, encompassing both quantitative and qualitative approaches, as well as soft skills. Here, I provide a brief listing of the most pertinent skills that I’ve recently applied and which could be valuable for organizations in diverse fields.






The ability to accurately identify and quantify patterns in various contexts through mathematical precision is crucial due to its significant relevance and transformative potential.



📌 Statistical analysis.


My relationship with statistics dates back more than 10 years, starting from my first class at the University of Buenos Aires. Beyond my conceptual interest and analysis in research environments, I applied my knowledge during my time at CEPAL, where I contributed to the development of a Consumer Price Index (CPI) and other economic indicators in collaboration with Argentine government organizations.
More recently, as part of my doctoral thesis, I worked on models for categorical, binomial, and multinomial variables to analyze data from online surveys, which I not only analyzed but also designed and distributed using Qualtrics. The final analysis in the thesis utilized a complex version of the proportional odds model (McCullagh 1980), which allows representing ordinal categorical variables (such as Likert scale) as dependent variables. Just for illustrative purposes, the following graph shows how different satisfaction levels associated with various modes of collaboration vary according to the age of collaborators.



Code
# Full model plots: appending fitted response probabilities (or logits) to the data frame and plotting these in relation to the predictors.
#using the predict() fuction with option type = "probs" to get probabilities instead the highest probability category
collab_DF <- cbind(collaborators %>% 
                     dplyr::select(Q15_1_collapsed, edad, chann), 
                   predict(om_151, type = "probs"))

# long format data for plotting
plot_dat <- collab_DF %>% 
  pivot_longer(c(Negativo, Neutral, Positivo), names_to = "level", values_to = "prob")

gg <- ggplot(plot_dat, aes(x = edad, y = prob, colour = level)) + geom_line(size = 1) + theme_bw() + xlim(25, 80) + geom_point(color = "black", size = 0.2) + facet_grid(chann ~ .) 

gg










📌 Social network analysis in R and Gephi.


While my primary focus has been on statistical, descriptive, and inferential analysis, I’ve also delved into graph theory and social network analysis. Although I didn’t extensively research it due to the requirements of my thesis, I’ve utilized packages like Bibliometrix and others to measure collaborations between academic and business organizations through joint publications.
The endeavor wasn’t highly successful because very few businesses publish, but it did serve as a means to examine collaborations between academic organizations and practice network analysis. This allowed me to explore collaborations in the academic sphere and practice network analysis. For instance, I’ve been able to depict the evolution of collaborations in academic publications among various organizations in the city of Bariloche, Argentina. Below, you can find two graphical representations of collaborations in Bariloche, one in network form (left) and the other geographically (right). If you’d like to see more comprehensive results, you can watch my presentation at the Networks 2021: Joint Sunbelt & NetSci Conference here.



Code
library(tidygeocoder)
library(maps)
library(mapdata)
library(geosphere)
library(geodist)
library("animation") 

#### ILLUSTRATION CODE EXCERPTS FOR GIFS CREATION #### 

## GRAPH A (left) ----

# source: https://kateto.net/network-visualization
library("igraph")
local_g <- list()
local_comp <- list()
saveGIF({
for (i in loop.vector) {
  vert <- V(g_list[[i]])[which(V(g_list[[i]])$bariloche == 1 | V(g_list[[i]])$bariloche == 2)]
  #get edges connected to selected nodes: https://igraph.org/r/doc/incident_edges.html
  edg <- incident_edges(g_list[[i]], vert, "all")
  local <- ego(g_list[[i]], order = 1, nodes = vert, mode = "all")
  local_g[[i]] <- igraph::subgraph.edges(g_list[[i]], eids = unlist(edg)) 
  local_comp[[i]] <- decompose(local_g[[i]])
  V(local_comp[[i]][[1]])$deg <- degree(local_comp[[i]][[1]])
  E(local_comp[[i]][[1]])$width <- 12*E(local_comp[[i]][[1]])$weight/max(E(local_comp[[i]][[1]])$weight)
  l = layout_with_fr(local_comp[[i]][[1]])
  plot(local_comp[[i]][[1]], 
       vertex.size = 1+V(local_comp[[i]][[1]])$deg/max(V(local_comp[[i]][[1]])$deg)*10, vertex.label = "", 
       edge.width = E(local_comp[[i]][[1]])$width,
       layout = l, 
       main = paste0("Bariloche's academic organization","\n", "ego network (largest component)" ,"\n",names(Mslice)[i])
       )
}
},interval = .8, movie.name = "bch_institutional_animation.gif")


#### GRAPH B (right) ----

g <- g_list[[i]]

# Join features
g <- contract(g,
         factor(V(g)$name),
         vertex.attr.comb = list(name = "first", group = "mean", docs = "max", "random"))
# attributes were merged: docs max as most of interactions are shared
g <- simplify(g, remove.loops=T, remove.multiple = T, edge.attr.comb =  list(weight = "max"))

# generate data frames of organizations and collaborations
un_geo_data = igraph::as_data_frame(g, what = 'both')  # affiliation network from bibliometrix as data frame

orgs <- un_geo_data$vertices %>% 
  mutate(lat = as.numeric(lat),
         long = as.numeric(long))

# Keep collaborations only with egos from BCH
un_geo_data$edges$width <- NULL
collabs <- as_tibble(un_geo_data$edges) %>% 
  filter(from %in% vert$name | to %in% vert$name) 

# World Map (low quality, should be improved)
map("world", col = "grey20", fill = T, bg = "black", lwd = 0.1)
title(paste(unique(orgs$year)), col.main = "lightgrey")
#plot(gadm, col = myColours, border = 'grey')

points(x = orgs$long, y=orgs$lat, cex = .04+orgs$docs/max(orgs$docs), col = "yellow")

for(j in 1:nrow(collabs)) {
    node1 <- orgs[orgs$name == collabs[j,]$from,]
    node2 <- orgs[orgs$name == collabs[j,]$to,]
    if (!is.na(node1$lat) & !is.na(node2$lat) & node1$lat != node2$lat)
      {
    arc <- gcIntermediate(c(node1[1,]$long, node1[1,]$lat), 
                           c(node2[1,]$long, node2[1,]$lat), 
                           n=30, addStartEnd=TRUE, breakAtDateLine = T, sp=T)
    edge.ind <- 1# round(60*collabs[j,]$weight / max(collabs$weight))
    
    lines(arc, col=edge.col[edge.ind], lwd=edge.ind/5)

    }
}
}
},interval = .5, movie.name = "bchDynamicInfoMap.gif")

 detach('package:animation')



















Besides employing the quantitative approach, I’ve also engaged extensively with qualitative methods. Although my exposure to this area is not as extensive, I’ve found their significant capability in offering intricate insights and contextual information.



📌 Interviews and case studies.


I had conducted interviews for my master’s thesis, and more recently, for my doctoral thesis, I analyzed 26 interviews using Atlas.ti. The preparation of interviews, contacting interviewees, conducting the interviews, and transcription are essential parts of this process (rubin2011?; kvale1994?). For the analysis, I employed thematic analysis (Braun and Clarke 2006), based on a list of a priori codes, which I later updated with emerging themes. Analyzing interviews can be a demanding task, but it provides valuable insights from multiple individuals with direct experience in the subject of study. Below is a screenshot of the thematic analysis process in Atlas.ti. In the future, I am excited about the prospect of conducting focus groups.











I had my first experience with mixed methods during my doctoral thesis, following the guidance of (creswell2017?) and (tashakkori1998?). Despite their complexity in design and implementation, mixed methods offer an alternative that allows us to combine the strengths of both quantitative and qualitative approaches, and even incorporate other methodologies and theoretical frameworks.



📌 Quantitative and qualitative data integration.


In my case, I adapted and implemented an “explanatory sequential case study design”. Starting with the selection of a specific case study, this design initiates with a quantitative phase to identify aggregated behavioral patterns. The analysis of these results then guides the subsequent qualitative phase, aimed at achieving a deeper and more nuanced understanding of the aggregated patterns. Finally, the results from both phases are integrated, providing a more comprehensive outcome.












In addition to this list of technical skills, I have also developed other social competencies that are essential for achieving objectives, whether individually or collectively. These “soft skills” are associated with communication and personality traits that facilitate interpersonal relationships and intelligent navigation of one’s environment. Here is a brief list enumerating the main aptitudes I continuously work on and consider valuable for my professional ecosystem:


📌 Complex Problem Solving:

I’m passionate about tackling complex issues and devising concrete solutions that avoid falling into simplistic and reductionist proposals. With a proactive and open-minded attitude, I seek to design sophisticated, “out-of-the-box” solutions that not only consider the parts of a process but also their connections and interdependencies. In the design and implementation of my doctoral thesis, I faced all sorts of challenges (methodological, scheduling, resource limitations) that I could address and frame to provide an integrated response from a complex perspective.



📌 Target Communication:

Effective communication is crucial in my professional approach. I adjust technical language to understandable terms and adapt the message format according to the context and the recipient. This has been essential in my role as an intermediary between academia and industry.



📌 Collaborative and Independent Work Balance:

Conceiving and carrying out a research project from start to finish has taught me to work autonomously. However, at the same time, being part of a research group and participating in multiple conferences have shown me the value of sharing and actively collaborating to achieve collective goals. Collaboration is key to enhancing individual skills and achieving better collective results.



📌 Resilience and Adaptability:

I’m excited by the continuous evolution of events and technology. I believe that challenges represent growth opportunities, for which it is necessary to embrace change and quickly incorporate new tools, methods, and work modalities. Whether through self-learning or thanks to the training offered by the organizations I’ve been a part of, I always take the initiative to master new tools and make the most of their adaptation to the needs and context.






📌 Pandoc / Markdown
📌 Prompt Engineering
📌 Decidim
📌 Other software and languages I’ve used: Microsoft Office, Zettlr, Stata, REDATAM, QGIS, Gephi, Freeplane, Zotero, \(LaTeX\), Python, Java.

  plot(local_comp[[i]][[1]], 
       vertex.size = 1+V(local_comp[[i]][[1]])$deg/max(V(local_comp[[i]][[1]])$deg)*10, vertex.label = "",

       )
}

#### GRAPH B (right) ----

g <- g_list[[i]]

# Join features
g <- contract(g,
         factor(V(g)$name),
         vertex.attr.comb = list(name = "first", group = "mean", docs = "max", "random"))
# attributes were merged: docs max as most of interactions are shared
g <- simplify(g, remove.loops=T, remove.multiple = T, edge.attr.comb =  list(weight = "max"))

# generate data frames of organizations and collaborations

orgs <- un_geo_data$vertices %>% 
  mutate(lat = as.numeric(lat),

# Keep collaborations only with egos from BCH

collabs <- as_tibble(un_geo_data$edges) %>%

Besides employing the quantitative approach, I’ve also engaged extensively with qualitative methods. Although my exposure to this area is not as extensive, I’ve found their significant capability in offering intricate insights and contextual information.



📌 Interviews and case studies.


I had conducted interviews for my master’s thesis, and more recently, for my doctoral thesis, I analyzed 26 interviews using Atlas.ti. The preparation of interviews, contacting interviewees, conducting the interviews, and transcription are essential parts of this process (rubin2011?; kvale1994?). For the analysis, I employed thematic analysis (Braun and Clarke 2006), based on a list of a priori codes, which I later updated with emerging themes. Analyzing interviews can be a demanding task, but it provides valuable insights from multiple individuals with direct experience in the subject of study. Below is a screenshot of the thematic analysis process in Atlas.ti. In the future, I am excited about the prospect of conducting focus groups.











I had my first experience with mixed methods during my doctoral thesis, following the guidance of (creswell2017?) and (tashakkori1998?). Despite their complexity in design and implementation, mixed methods offer an alternative that allows us to combine the strengths of both quantitative and qualitative approaches, and even incorporate other methodologies and theoretical frameworks.



📌 Quantitative and qualitative data integration.


In my case, I adapted and implemented an “explanatory sequential case study design”. Starting with the selection of a specific case study, this design initiates with a quantitative phase to identify aggregated behavioral patterns. The analysis of these results then guides the subsequent qualitative phase, aimed at achieving a deeper and more nuanced understanding of the aggregated patterns. Finally, the results from both phases are integrated, providing a more comprehensive outcome.

title: My Skills
text:
In addition to this list of technical skills, I have also developed other social competencies that are essential for achieving objectives, whether individually or collectively. These “soft skills” are associated with communication and personality traits that facilitate interpersonal relationships and intelligent navigation of one’s environment. Here is a brief list enumerating the main aptitudes I continuously work on and consider valuable for my professional ecosystem:


📌 Complex Problem Solving:

I’m passionate about tackling complex issues and devising concrete solutions that avoid falling into simplistic and reductionist proposals. With a proactive and open-minded attitude, I seek to design sophisticated, “out-of-the-box” solutions that not only consider the parts of a process but also their connections and interdependencies. In the design and implementation of my doctoral thesis, I faced all sorts of challenges (methodological, scheduling, resource limitations) that I could address and frame to provide an integrated response from a complex perspective.



📌 Target Communication:

Effective communication is crucial in my professional approach. I adjust technical language to understandable terms and adapt the message format according to the context and the recipient. This has been essential in my role as an intermediary between academia and industry.



📌 Collaborative and Independent Work Balance:

Conceiving and carrying out a research project from start to finish has taught me to work autonomously. However, at the same time, being part of a research group and participating in multiple conferences have shown me the value of sharing and actively collaborating to achieve collective goals. Collaboration is key to enhancing individual skills and achieving better collective results.



📌 Resilience and Adaptability:

I’m excited by the continuous evolution of events and technology. I believe that challenges represent growth opportunities, for which it is necessary to embrace change and quickly incorporate new tools, methods, and work modalities. Whether through self-learning or thanks to the training offered by the organizations I’ve been a part of, I always take the initiative to master new tools and make the most of their adaptation to the needs and context.

title: Academic and Professional Interests
text:
Academic and Professional Interests


In addition to my professional skills, my career has led me to explore various areas of knowledge that have left a mark on my worldview. Here, I describe some areas that have particularly captured my attention:


Complexity Theory and Information Theory

🧩 Exploring the complexity of phenomena. 📚 Resources and enthusiasm for emergent properties, entropy (Ben-Naim 2008), the groundbreaking work of Claude Shannon (1949), and subsequent studies in various knowledge areas (e.g., Boisot and Canals 2004; Gleick 2011; Snowden 2002; Polyanskiy and Wu 2022).



Graph Theory and Network Analysis

🌐 Unraveling relationships beyond the actors. 🔗 Representing complexity as interconnected and interdependent systems, considering both nodes and the links that connect them (Börner, Sanyal, and Vespignani 2007; M. S. Granovetter 1973; M. Granovetter 1983; Newman 2018).



Economics, Institutions, and Culture

💼 Exploring the socio-cultural foundations of economic behavior. 📖 Interdisciplinary research on how culture and institutions influence the management of resources, information, and knowledge. The list of references here is extensive, but beyond pure economics, it’s worth mentioning works in innovation systems (Cooke 2001; Etzkowitz and Leydesdorff 2000; Lundvall 1988; Nelson and Rosenberg 1993), open innovation (Chesbrough 2003; Von Hippel 2005), commons (Allen and Potts 2016; Hess and Ostrom 2007; Kostakis, Niaros, and Giotitsas 2015; Ostrom 1990), and information economics (Boisot 1998).



Organizational Theory and Knowledge Management

🏘️ Studying strategies for the collective production of knowledge 📦 Another field with a wealth of literature. Besides countless classic references (e.g., Alavi and Leidner 2001; Cetina 1999; March 1991; Nonaka and Takeuchi 1995; Polanyi 1958; Teece, Pisano, and Shuen 1997), I highlight the theoretical framework developed by Boisot (1995) for understanding information and knowledge flows in social settings: the Information Space or I-Space. Coding, abstraction, and diffusion are three key dimensions used to analyze the ongoing production of knowledge (Boisot et al. 2011).



Platforms and Digitalization

🗂️ Navigating the Digital Age. 📊 Exploring the phenomenon of platforms and their widespread impact on contemporary economy. I’m particularly drawn to theoretical perspectives like Gawer (2020). Understanding how these platforms are reshaping economic and social interactions is fundamental. We’ve written something on the topic.



Philosophy: Pragmatism, Enactivism, Education, Psychology

🧠 Philosophy in action. 📜 Exploring pragmatist approaches (Dewey 1923), enactivists (Varela, Thompson, and Rosch 2017), and their application in fields like education and psychology (e.g., Bereiter and Scardamalia 2014; Kress 2009; Scardamalia and Bereiter 2010).



Zettelkasten

🗂️ Creative organization. 🤯 The Zettelkasten technique as a source of idea generation and thought organization (Ahrens 2022).



Languages

🗣️ Connecting through language. 🌎 My passion for understanding cultural differences and communication patterns has inevitably led me to learn languages. In addition to my fluency in Spanish, English, Italian, and active study of Catalan, I can communicate in French. I would love to continue learning other languages.
